docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's largest health insurers, is in discussions to buy the health care subsidiary of the New York Life Insurance Company in a deal that would be valued at about $1 billion. An agreement to buy the unit, NYLCare Health Plans, is expected to be reached within the next few weeks, people close to the deal said yesterday. Spokesmen for Aetna and New York Life declined to comment on whether their companies were in negotiations. But the people close to the deal said the talks had been under way for some time and were moving toward conclusion.

headline.main: Aetna Is Said To Seek Deal In Health Care

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc, one of nation's largest insurers, is in talks to buy NYLCare Health Plans, health care unit of New York Life Insurance, in deal that would be valued at about $1 billion; Aetna is seeking to sell its life insurance and focus increasing on health care operations; NYLCare provides coverage to about 2.5 million people, about 1.5 million of them in managed care networks; it provides coverage in every state but is strongest in metropolitan New York, Washington-Baltimore region and in Texas; company lost $30 million last year (M)
docs.snippet: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's largest health insurers, is in discussions to buy the health care subsidiary of the New York Life Insurance Company in a deal that would be valued at about $1 billion.    An agreement to buy the unit, NYLCare Health...

docs.lead_paragraph: For more than a half century, Dr. Benjamin Spock has been the sage of sensible parenting, dispensing advice on matters from croup to hyperactivity in his enduring book, ''Baby and Child Care.'' But now it is the baby doctor who needs help, according to his wife, who this week issued a highly unusual appeal for donations to subsidize costly home health care for the ailing 94-year-old pediatrician and author. With their savings drained by bills for 24-hour nursing, a macrobiotic chef, yoga therapy, twice-weekly psychoanalysis and shiatsu massage, Mary Morgan, Dr. Spock's wife of 21 years, said she decided to turn to friends for help through a letter-writing campaign and a series of fund-raising parties to coincide with the publication of the seventh revised edition of the baby book on the author's birthday, May 2.

headline.main: Dr. Spock, Old and Infirm, Needs Money, Wife Says

docs.abstract: Dr Benjamin Spock, whose book, Baby and Child Care, has been veritable bible to generations of new parents, is now 94 and ailing; his wife of 21 years, Mary Morgan, has issued highly unusual appeal for donations to subsidize costly home health care for him; says their savings have been drained by bills for 24-hour nursing, macrobiotic chef, yoga therapy, twice-weekly psychoanalysis and shiatsu massage; Morgan concedes there is split in family about whether her husband should be moved into nursing home; Spock's two sons from previous marriage refuse to comment about Morgan's appeal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-5 Queen Backs Changing Royal Rules for Succession Changing 800 years of royal practice, Queen Elizabeth told Parliament that she approved of a plan to end the tradition of the firstborn son succeeding to the British throne. This would mean that Prince William's eldest child would follow him to the throne, whether a girl or boy. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Federal Government faces three significant car safety issues, but the Transportation Department has neatly sidestepped one, on air bags, stilling a public outcry about their occasional dangers without disabling many bags. On another, drunken driving, both houses of Congress may take up debate for the first time on a national standard. But action seems less likely on the third issue, seat belts, which is probably the most important of the three in terms of lives at risk. After all the sound and fury over air bags, only 18,000 people have requested permission to install on-off switches since the Government liberalized the rules in November. From 100 to 200 applications arrive daily.

headline.main: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; 3 Issues Test Resolve Of Federal Regulators

docs.abstract: Federal legislation sponsored by Reprs Nita Lowey and Sen Frank Lautenberg would deny Federal highway aid to states that do not adopt drunk-driving standard of 0.08 percent blood alcohol; most states have 0.10 percent standard; photo of checkpoint in North Carolina, which has cracked down aggressively on drunken driving; status of laws on air bags and seat belts also noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The five Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurers in New York State announced yesterday that they would voluntarily submit disputes with patients who are denied medical coverage to an independent third party for review. In the past, with a few exceptions, patients who had been denied coverage could appeal only through an insurer's own review -- a process that has come under increasing fire from legislators and consumer groups.

headline.main: Insurer Sets Review Plan For Disputes

docs.abstract: Five Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurers in New York State announce that they will voluntarily submit disputes with patients who are denied medical coverage to independent third party for review; Blue Cross is first managed-care company in New York to agree to outside review process (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Even as a physician, I worked night shifts at a moonlighting job to pay for infertility treatments not covered by my employer-sponsored health plan (front page, Feb. 22).

headline.main: Covering Infertility Won't Hurt the Uninsured

docs.abstract: Dr Ellen Morrison letter on question of paying for infertility treatments; holds there is are no data to suggest that exclusion of insurance coverage for infertility has resulted in improved access to care for the underinsured or uninsured

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors, patients and advocates for the poor and for retired people spoke out in opposition today to a plan by Vytra Healthcare, the largest health maintenance organization on Long Island, to convert to profit-making status and sell shares on the stock market. ''The bottom line would be bigger profits for shareholders instead of better health care,'' said Fred Treubig, a Vytra subscriber who recently retired and lives in Farmingdale.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Plan To Seek Profits Draws Criticism

docs.abstract: New York State Atty Gen Dennis C Vacco holds public hearing on plan by Vytra Healthcare, largest health maintenance organization on Long Island, to convert to profit-making status and sell shares on stock market; doctors, patients and advocates for poor and retired people oppose plan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O's president, brought the labor movement's road show to the Big Apple yesterday to hear what was on the minds of New York City's workers -- and they gave him an earful. New York's never-timid workers addressed him the way they would a governor or even a president, urging him and the labor movement to help fix their problems, large and small: inadequate child care, expensive housing and insecurity on the job.

headline.main: Labor Chief Visits to Rally Unions and Hear Workers' Hopes

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO pres John J Sweeney attends town meeting at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and visits day care center in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, to hear what is on minds of New York City's workers; they urge him and labor movement to help fix problems such as inadequate child care, expensive housing and insecurity on job; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The issue of insurance coverage for infertility (front page, Feb. 22) is not just about outcome -- the birth of a child. Instead, the focus must remain on treatment for the disease. Infertility is defined as a disease by the American Society for Reproductive Medicine and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. As such, it warrants medically appropriate treatment.

headline.main: Covering Infertility Won't Hurt the Uninsured; Truly a Disease

docs.abstract: Diane D Aronson letter on issue of insurance coverage for infertility; notes that infertility is defined as a disease by American Society for Reproductive Medicine, and as such warrants medically appropriate treatment

docs.lead_paragraph: In a case that Federal officials described as ground-breaking, the Israel Discount Bank of New York agreed last week to provide people suffering from mental disability the same long-term benefits that are available for physical conditions. A former assistant vice president of the bank, identified in court papers only as Leonard F., now 53, sued his employer under the Americans with Disabilities Act after he suffered a nervous breakdown in 1994 and was no longer able to work.

headline.main: Metro Business; Bank Settles Benefits Case
